awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Collaborative: Personalized Cybersecurity Education and Training
awd_abstract_narration:
The average citizen is often unaware of common strategies to protect themselves from cybersecurity threats.   Consequently, large numbers of computer users are vulnerable to lapses in security from actions such as choosing weak passwords, clicking on phishing links, opening attachments from unknown senders, ignoring security warnings on devices, and falling victim to social engineering or identity theft. Although there have been many studies on training and educating people on cybersecurity best practices, the fact that these vulnerabilities are still being exploited imply that current training is not effective for all users.  The objective of this project is to effectively educate the average user about common cybersecurity threats so that they are not vulnerable to these types of attacks.   The project will create new education modules that are personalized to each user, building on the fact that different users have different personalities and may react to threats in different ways.  The result could be more cybersecurity-aware citizens, which could reduce the number of "easy" hacks and cyber thefts. 

It has already been shown that different models are needed to effectively educate individuals with different personality traits and learning behaviors. There is no "one-size-fits-all" model. The researchers' aims are to 1) increase cybersecurity compliance with schema matching messages, and 2) develop and evaluate the effectiveness of cybersecurity education modules. The researchers have shown that individual differences in personality traits can be used to predict cybersecurity perceptions and practices. The research will classify personalities through analysis of the language of social media. Personalized cybersecurity education modules will then be developed and evaluated. Users' personalities will be assigned based on the "True Colors" Personality Categories, which are based on the Myers-Briggs personality categories, and the Big Five Personality traits. This personalized education module approach could be applied in other areas such as management, teaching, and safety training. Moreover, users will become more security-aware which could lead to a reduction in cybersecurity breaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The average citizen of the world has little awareness of cybersecurity issues. Consequently, large numbers of computer users are vulnerable to lapses in security, such as choosing weak passwords, clicking on phishing links, opening attachments, ignoring security warnings on devices, and falling victim to social engineering or identity theft. Although there have been many studies on training and educating people on security best practices, the fact that these vulnerabilities are still being exploited leads us to conclude that these types of training are not effective. There have been improvements in technology, but there is only so much technology can accomplish to prevent security problems. 


It is widely known that different people have different personalities such as the Big Five Personality traits, risk-taking, decision-making styles, and True Colors personality. The four True Colors personalities are “blue” for caring and sensitivity people, “orange” for a risk-taking individual, “gold” for a leader-type personality, and “green” for an organizing role model. The True Colors® Personality is widely used in employment settings across a wide array of industries. The Big Five personalities are conscientiousness, extroversion, agreeableness, openness, and mood stability. It has been shown that different models are needed to effectively educate all the different personality traits and learning styles. There is no “one-size-fits-all” model. 


The first outcome of this project is that experimental results show that cybersecurity awareness is linked to personality traits. Our results showed that a personality type was more likely to choose stronger passwords. A targeted nudging training module was developed and results show that participants tended to create stronger passwords after undergoing this personalized training based on matching and mismatching messages based on personality. This could potentially lead to better security and better more personalized training to employees and to the general public.


The second outcome of this project is that results found that decision-making styles are better predictors at whether someone falls victim to a phishing email than protective strategies or prior victimization. Thus, all the cybersecurity awareness messaging about phishing might not be as effective and it might be better to focus on decision-making styles and anxiety levels of users.


Overall, this project resulted in over a dozen peer-reviewed publications, over a dozen posters, and one talk. The project also involved the creation of a new dual-credit cybersecurity course which includes cyber crime and elements of psychology – that course could be taken by non-cybersecurity majors and high school students. The project contributed to the education of hundreds of undergraduate and graduate students in computer science/cybersecurity and psychology through class lectures and the training of 14 undergraduate students and two graduate students at Loyola University and 5 undergraduates and 3 graduate students at OSU. Four of those undergraduate students from Loyola University decided to further their education by obtaining a graduate degree.
